sn35.132:2.3.en: Their sense doors were guarded, well protected,

sn35.132:5.1.en: All is vain for someone who doesn’t guard the sense doors,

sn35.132:12.1.en: “Master Kaccāna spoke of someone who doesn’t guard the sense doors.

sn35.132:12.2.pli: Kittāvatā nu kho, bho kaccāna, aguttadvāro hotī”ti?
sn35.132:12.2.en: How do you define someone who doesn’t guard the sense doors?”

sn35.132:12.11.en: That’s how someone doesn’t guard the sense doors.”

sn35.132:13.1.en: You also spoke of someone who does guard the sense doors.

sn35.132:13.2.pli: Kittāvatā nu kho, bho kaccāna, guttadvāro hotī”ti?
sn35.132:13.2.en: How do you define someone who does guard the sense doors?”

sn35.132:13.11.en: That’s how someone guards the sense doors.”

sn35.120:2.1.pli: “Evametaṁ, āvuso, hoti indriyesu aguttadvārassa, bhojane amattaññuno, jāgariyaṁ ananuyuttassa.
sn35.120:2.1.en: “That’s how it is, reverend, when someone doesn’t guard the sense doors, eats too much, and is not committed to wakefulness.

sn35.120:2.3.pli: ‘So vatāvuso, bhikkhu indriyesu guttadvāro, bhojane mattaññū, jāgariyaṁ anuyutto yāvajīvaṁ paripuṇṇaṁ parisuddhaṁ brahmacariyaṁ santānessatī’ti ṭhānametaṁ vijjati.
sn35.120:2.3.en: But it is possible for a mendicant to maintain the full and pure spiritual life for the rest of their life if they guard the sense doors, eat in moderation, and are committed to wakefulness.

sn35.120:3.1.en: And how does someone guard the sense doors?

sn35.120:3.10.pli: Evaṁ kho, āvuso, indriyesu guttadvāro hoti.
sn35.120:3.10.en: That’s how someone guards the sense doors.

sn35.120:5.8.pli: ‘indriyesu guttadvārā bhavissāma, bhojane mattaññuno, jāgariyaṁ anuyuttā’ti.
sn35.120:5.8.en: ‘We will guard the sense doors, eat in moderation, and be committed to wakefulness.’

mlDocs.title:
Linked Discourses 35
12. The World and the Kinds of Sensual Stimulation
120. Sāriputta and the Pupil

mn53:6.2.pli: “idha, mahānāma, ariyasāvako sīlasampanno hoti, indriyesu guttadvāro hoti, bhojane mattaññū hoti, jāgariyaṁ anuyutto hoti, sattahi saddhammehi samannāgato hoti, catunnaṁ jhānānaṁ ābhicetasikānaṁ diṭṭhadhammasukhavihārānaṁ nikāmalābhī hoti akicchalābhī akasiralābhī.
mn53:6.2.en: “Mahānāma, a noble disciple is accomplished in ethics, guards the sense doors, eats in moderation, and is dedicated to wakefulness. They have seven good qualities, and they get the four absorptions—blissful meditations in the present life that belong to the higher mind—when they want, without trouble or difficulty.

mn53:8.1.pli: Kathañca, mahānāma, ariyasāvako indriyesu guttadvāro hoti?
mn53:8.1.en: And how does a noble disciple guard the sense doors?

mn53:8.10.pli: Evaṁ kho, mahānāma, ariyasāvako indriyesu guttadvāro hoti.
mn53:8.10.en: That’s how a noble disciple guards the sense doors.

mn53:19.1.pli: Yato kho, mahānāma, ariyasāvako evaṁ sīlasampanno hoti, evaṁ indriyesu guttadvāro hoti, evaṁ bhojane mattaññū hoti, evaṁ jāgariyaṁ anuyutto hoti, evaṁ sattahi saddhammehi samannāgato hoti, evaṁ catunnaṁ jhānānaṁ ābhicetasikānaṁ diṭṭhadhammasukhavihārānaṁ nikāmalābhī hoti akicchalābhī akasiralābhī, ayaṁ vuccati, mahānāma, ariyasāvako sekho pāṭipado apuccaṇḍatāya samāpanno, bhabbo abhinibbhidāya, bhabbo sambodhāya, bhabbo anuttarassa yogakkhemassa adhigamāya.
mn53:19.1.en: When a noble disciple is accomplished in ethics, guards the sense doors, eats in moderation, and is dedicated to wakefulness; and they have seven good qualities, and they get the four absorptions—blissful meditations in the present life that belong to the higher mind—when they want, without trouble or difficulty, they are called a noble disciple who is a practicing trainee. Their eggs are unspoiled, and they are capable of breaking out of their shell, becoming awakened, and achieving the supreme sanctuary.

mn53:23.2.pli: yampi, mahānāma, ariyasāvako indriyesu guttadvāro hoti, idampissa hoti caraṇasmiṁ;

an3.16:1.3.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu indriyesu guttadvāro hoti, bhojane mattaññū hoti, jāgariyaṁ anuyutto hoti.
an3.16:1.3.en: It’s when a mendicant guards the sense doors, eats in moderation, and is dedicated to wakefulness.

an3.16:2.1.pli: Kathañca, bhikkhave, bhikkhu indriyesu guttadvāro hoti?
an3.16:2.1.en: And how does a mendicant guard the sense doors?

an3.16:2.10.pli: Evaṁ kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu indriyesu guttadvāro hoti.
an3.16:2.10.en: That’s how a mendicant guards the sense doors.

sn35.239:1.3.pli: Indriyesu guttadvāro hoti, bhojane mattaññū, jāgariyaṁ anuyutto.
sn35.239:1.3.en: They guard the sense doors, eat in moderation, and are committed to wakefulness.

sn35.239:2.1.pli: Kathañca, bhikkhave, bhikkhu indriyesu guttadvāro hoti?
sn35.239:2.1.en: And how does a mendicant guard the sense doors?

sn35.239:2.12.pli: Evaṁ kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu indriyesu guttadvāro hoti.
sn35.239:2.12.en: That’s how a mendicant guards the sense doors.

mlDocs.title:

an4.37:1.3.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu sīlasampanno hoti, indriyesu guttadvāro hoti, bhojane mattaññū hoti, jāgariyaṁ anuyutto hoti.
an4.37:1.3.en: A mendicant is accomplished in ethics, guards the sense doors, eats in moderation, and is dedicated to wakefulness.

an4.37:3.1.pli: Kathañca, bhikkhave, bhikkhu indriyesu guttadvāro hoti?
an4.37:3.1.en: And how does a mendicant guard the sense doors?

an4.37:3.10.pli: Evaṁ kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu indriyesu guttadvāro hoti.
an4.37:3.10.en: That’s how a mendicant guards the sense doors.

mn69:10.1.en: A wilderness monk should guard the sense doors.

mn69:10.3.pli: ‘Kiṁ panimassāyasmato āraññikassa ekassāraññe serivihārena yo ayamāyasmā indriyesu aguttadvāro’ti—
mn69:10.3.en: ‘What’s the point of this wilderness venerable’s staying alone and autonomous in the wilderness, since he doesn’t guard the sense doors?’

mn69:10.5.pli: Tasmā āraññikena bhikkhunā indriyesu guttadvārena bhavitabbaṁ.
mn69:10.5.en: That’s why a wilderness monk should guard the sense doors.

dn10:1.10.1.pli: So evaṁ pabbajito samāno pātimokkhasaṁvarasaṁvuto viharati, ācāragocarasampanno, anumattesu vajjesu bhayadassāvī, samādāya sikkhati sikkhāpadesu, kāyakammavacīkammena samannāgato kusalena, parisuddhājīvo, sīlasampanno, indriyesu guttadvāro, satisampajaññena samannāgato, santuṭṭho.
dn10:1.10.1.en: Once they’ve gone forth, they live restrained in the monastic code, conducting themselves well and seeking alms in suitable places. Seeing danger in the slightest fault, they keep the rules they’ve undertaken. They act skillfully by body and speech. They’re purified in livelihood and accomplished in ethical conduct. They guard the sense doors, have mindfulness and situational awareness, and are content.

dn10:2.2.1.en: “And how, student, does a mendicant guard the sense doors?

dn10:2.2.11.pli: Evaṁ kho, māṇava, bhikkhu indriyesu guttadvāro hoti.
dn10:2.2.11.en: That’s how a mendicant guards the sense doors.

dn2:42.1.pli: So evaṁ pabbajito samāno pātimokkhasaṁvarasaṁvuto viharati ācāragocarasampanno, aṇumattesu vajjesu bhayadassāvī, samādāya sikkhati sikkhāpadesu, kāyakammavacīkammena samannāgato kusalena, parisuddhājīvo sīlasampanno, indriyesu guttadvāro, satisampajaññena samannāgato, santuṭṭho.
dn2:42.1.en: Once they’ve gone forth, they live restrained in the monastic code, conducting themselves well and seeking alms in suitable places. Seeing danger in the slightest fault, they keep the rules they’ve undertaken. They act skillfully by body and speech. They’re purified in livelihood and accomplished in ethical conduct. They guard the sense doors, have mindfulness and situational awareness, and are content.

dn2:64.1.pli: Kathañca, mahārāja, bhikkhu indriyesu guttadvāro hoti?
dn2:64.1.en: And how does a mendicant guard the sense doors?

dn2:64.11.pli: Evaṁ kho, mahārāja, bhikkhu indriyesu guttadvāro hoti.
dn2:64.11.en: That’s how a mendicant guards the sense doors.

mlDocs.title:
Long Discourses 2
The Fruits of the Ascetic Life
1. A Discussion With the King’s Ministers

an6.31:1.3.pli: Kammārāmatā, bhassārāmatā, niddārāmatā, saṅgaṇikārāmatā, indriyesu aguttadvāratā, bhojane amattaññutā—
an6.31:1.3.en: They relish work, talk, sleep, and company. They don’t guard the sense doors, and they eat too much.

an6.31:2.3.pli: Na kammārāmatā, na bhassārāmatā, na niddārāmatā, na saṅgaṇikārāmatā, indriyesu guttadvāratā, bhojane mattaññutā—
an6.31:2.3.en: They don’t relish work, talk, sleep, and company. They guard the sense doors, and they don’t eat too much.

an8.79:1.3.pli: Kammārāmatā, bhassārāmatā, niddārāmatā, saṅgaṇikārāmatā, indriyesu aguttadvāratā, bhojane amattaññutā, saṁsaggārāmatā, papañcārāmatā—
an8.79:1.3.en: They relish work, talk, sleep, and company. They don’t guard the sense doors and they eat too much. They relish closeness and proliferation.

an8.79:2.3.pli: Na kammārāmatā, na bhassārāmatā, na niddārāmatā, na saṅgaṇikārāmatā, indriyesu guttadvāratā, bhojane mattaññutā, asaṁsaggārāmatā, nippapañcārāmatā—
an8.79:2.3.en: They don’t relish work, talk, and sleep. They guard the sense doors, and they don’t eat too much. They don’t relish closeness and proliferation.

an7.28:1.6.pli: Kammārāmatā, bhassārāmatā, niddārāmatā, saṅgaṇikārāmatā, indriyesu aguttadvāratā, bhojane amattaññutā, santi kho pana saṅghe saṅghakaraṇīyāni; tatra sekho bhikkhu iti paṭisañcikkhati:
an7.28:1.6.en: They relish work, talk, sleep, and company. They don’t guard the sense doors and they eat too much. And when there is Saṅgha business to be carried out, they don’t reflect:

an7.28:2.3.pli: Na kammārāmatā, na bhassārāmatā, na niddārāmatā, na saṅgaṇikārāmatā, indriyesu guttadvāratā, bhojane mattaññutā, santi kho pana saṅghe saṅghakaraṇīyāni; tatra sekho bhikkhu iti paṭisañcikkhati:
an7.28:2.3.en: They don’t relish work, talk, sleep, and company. They guard the sense doors and don’t they eat too much. And when there is Saṅgha business to be carried out, they reflect:

an5.150:1.3.pli: Kammārāmatā, bhassārāmatā, niddārāmatā, indriyesu aguttadvāratā, bhojane amattaññutā.
an5.150:1.3.en: They relish work, talk, and sleep. They don’t guard the sense doors and they eat too much.

an5.150:2.3.pli: Na kammārāmatā, na bhassārāmatā, na niddārāmatā, indriyesu guttadvāratā, bhojane mattaññutā.
an5.150:2.3.en: They don’t relish work, talk, sleep, and company. They guard the sense doors and they have moderation in eating.

mlDocs.title:

150. Temporarily Free (2nd)

an1.230:1.1.en: … who guard the sense doors is Nanda.

dn8:18.4.pli: bhayadassāvī samādāya sikkhati sikkhāpadesu, kāyakammavacīkammena samannāgato kusalena parisuddhājīvo sīlasampanno indriyesu guttadvāro satisampajaññena samannāgato santuṭṭho.
dn8:18.4.en: Seeing danger in the slightest fault, a mendicant keeps the rules they’ve undertaken. They act skillfully by body and speech. They’re purified in livelihood and accomplished in ethical conduct. They guard the sense doors, have mindfulness and situational awareness, and are content.

mlDocs.title:
Long Discourses 8
The Longer Discourse on the Lion’s Roar

dn28:12.2.pli: Idha, bhante, ekacco sacco cassa saddho ca, na ca kuhako, na ca lapako, na ca nemittiko, na ca nippesiko, na ca lābhena lābhaṁ nijigīsanako, indriyesu guttadvāro, bhojane mattaññū, samakārī, jāgariyānuyogamanuyutto, atandito, āraddhavīriyo, jhāyī, satimā, kalyāṇapaṭibhāno, gatimā, dhitimā, matimā, na ca kāmesu giddho, sato ca nipako ca.
dn28:12.2.en: It’s when someone is honest and faithful. They don’t use deceit, flattery, hinting, or belittling, and they don’t use material possessions to chase after other material possessions. They guard the sense doors and eat in moderation. They’re fair, dedicated to wakefulness, tireless, energetic, and meditative. They have good memory, eloquence, range, retention, and thoughtfulness. They’re not greedy for sensual pleasures. They are mindful and alert.
